comments.text:
People care if any animals die out because the ecosystem is a lot more 
fragile then it seems. One species dying out could cause other species to 
overpopulate and case another species to die out and so on and so forth 
which could also end up causing problems for humanity itself since we, as 
animals, rely on other animals for food and other things. Its pretty much a 
domino effect that could have a much, much larger effect then most people 
would guess.

Beyond that, people also like animals..well, most people do..and no one 
wishes to see things go extinct (well, except for Mosquitoes..fuck

Dunning-Kruger is that very ignorant people tend to be overconfident 
whereas more knowledgable people are less confident even though they know 
more.

http://lexfridman.com/blogs/training/files/2014/08/Dunning-Kruger.jpg

You can search actual information if you'd prefer. 

You can not say that your mental abilities are god-like. That is absolutely 
unacceptable. That is the most ridiculous statement that one could possibly 
procure. 

Also, you can not resort to name calling when your opponent becomes 
belligerent. You definitely can not use derogatory terms such as retarded 
as that is a very insensitive thing to say. Even though someone says 
something you don't agree with, they're not necessarily dumb. People can be 
misled, come across misinformation, or buy into common misconceptions. It's 
not indicative of a lesser intelligence. However, do not stoop to the level 
of incessant badgering because you accomplish nothing but enrage the other 
party and leave them unreceptive to your reasoning.

comments.text:
+Olek Also I have the opposite of Dunning-Kruger. I underestimate how good 
I am at something until I have mastered it. Like when I was rank #6 I 
thought I was bad because 5 people where better than me. Emotionally I 
think I am bad at math even though I'm well above average. The reason is I 
compare myself to the best not the average person. If you look at the 
people above you, you'll be motivated to get on their level. If you look at 
the people below you, you'll be satisfied with your position and wont 
improve yourself. Pessimism isn't always a bad thing you know.

Nothing is fixed everything is acquired through practice. Newton and 
Einstein weren't born smart, they became gods at what they did through 
spending 1000s of hours crafting their talent. How much you value something 
dictates how good you are at it. Since I value philosophy and having sharp 
arguments, if an opponent makes a good point and I cannot think of a 
response on the spot, every now and then through out the day I will think 
about a counter argument while most people just wont respond, like peter 
pan for example. Even if I don't have an answer after a week I will still 
think about it until I do have an answer. To you it might sound obsessive, 
that's because it is. obsession is necessary to become the best at 
anything, singing, basketball, theoretical physics, whatever. Find your 
talent and craft it every single day.

comments.text:
Ah man, if you watch subs you eventually pick up a basic understanding of 
Japanese. I have a high-standard of subs now because i'm used to it. If I 
watch something and notice that the subs aren't accurate to what I know is 
being said it frustrates me.

Anyways. Crystal. The only reason Annie is not being forced out her crystal 
is because there's a fear if it shatters she'd die too. So what they're 
planning to do is A) as you say and wait it out. She won't have the power 
to keep it going forever. And D) is something Eren might do over-time but 
he needs time to train. I'm more interested in the rapid regeneration and 
flames as a side effect of that he seems like he might be able to control, 
but he was enranged and lost himself for a while, so again he'd need to 
train.

As for annoying. A, B and D are all true. I don't mind B though personally, 
I think it makes for interesting videos since you really want them to win 
and do well. Which is why AOT is so good since there's never that guarantee 
of "He's the main character, he won't die". Hell, I swear to God believed 
he had died. Hadn't seen him for 9 episodes or so, it must've been hell for 
those in Japan to wait that amount in weeks. As for C) I just think Eren is 
in too much of a dilemma with the vast amount of responsibility forced on 
him. He can't seem to accept the fact that there's others like him out 
there but that they want to destroy humanity, not help it. I wouldn't 
really say it's annoying moreso than it's temporary personality until he 
grasps the situation more maturely.

The ice wall? In Game of thrones though that 200+ metre wall is only one 
side of four. Not really good when the entire world is run over with 
Titans, they would be weak like any other to an attack elsewhere. And then 
there's the fact it'd have the same problems such as lack of manpower and 
resources. They wouldn't have an empire to back them up, they'd need to 
rely on themselves and they can't exactly go out and farm if there's very 
little defences. My GOT knowledge isn't the best though so feel free to 
correct me. As for B) season two! :D
They could very easily kill humanity, yes. At anytime, anyplace. But why? 
Why now? Why start there? Why didn't they just skip the little bait city 
and go straight in for the wall breach somewhere less defended instead of 
having to break two walls for the same result? This is something Eren can't 
understand and why there are humans killing humanity. We'll need to wait 
and find out!

those talented voice actors some work guys). Right now the closest thing 
I've seen in the west that compares is A:TLA and A:TLoK, and they're 
freaking Y7 nickelodeon cartoons. There's so much back and forth between 
our cultures it should be inevitable. My main gripes are with the dialogue, 
everything else is just nitpicking, you can tell that the monologues were 
likely pulled off the pages of the manga given their structure. This is 
however, a common trope in anime. It'd be nice to learn Japanese but I 
don't have that much time on my hands lol. 

As far as the crystal goes,

A. She would eventually starve or asphyxiate even in stasis.

B. Diamond is exceptionally hard but it is very fragile, a massive blunt 
object applied to the right point with the right point would shatter it.

C. All they need to do is bring her somewhere far underground, she won't 
escape.

D. If Eren could learn the same trick he could break it down.

Annoying,

A. the dub, nuff said.

B. I'm tired of the reckless, headstrong, and slightly thick character type 
that is inevitable in most shounen and western entertainment. It is done 
well here though.

C. He demands respect and understanding of others when he himself finds 
this difficult.

D. I'll say it again, the dub.

The Wall

A. Have you read game of thrones?

B. The colossal and armored Titan's are human's with a gift like Eren, If 
they were determined they could breach the walls. They could breach them at 
any point, also maintenance/killing of Titan's around the outer wall would 
be important.
comments.author: Nathan C.

comments.text:
+Nathan C.
I'm not surprised you're so confused, the English dub is shit. All dubs are 
to be honest minus a few. Anyways, since i'm bored and I love AOT, to 
answer your questions:

1) We do have effective artillery, we can break though their incredibly 
tough skin and bones to decapitate them but due to the fact they regerenate 
and the precision of said artillery is not reliable enough for destroying 
that small area on the back of the neck it's not commonly used. And given 
the recent attack ending the 100 years peace, we did indeed improve our 
fixed cannons. And said cannons were used over a cours of a week to empty a 
city filled with cannons, but that's a week of cannon fire. It takes some 
time.

2) Scouting at night is stupid. Sure, the titans are *slower* and more 
sluggish (not sleeping or knocked out)  but we rely on vision to 
effectively scout. Without it, we can't communicate to others. Flares would 
be easier to notice, granted, but what's the point if you can't spot the 
Titans you're trying to avoid? In an encounter, we also can't see where 
we're aiming or in the heat of the fight who is attacking which titan, etc. 
Leading to possible mid-air crashes.

3) Not sure what the Dub says, but people have already tried to survive in 
the mountains. Something tells me though that 30m monsters can climb the 
mountains easier than us though. Also, we're talking about 100 years or 
so+. Getting resources from a mountain or up and down a mountain would be 
very hard, and it'd offer no defence other than the height. Which again, 
have to stress, wouldn't kill the titans. A fall means nothing to them.

4) Because....we've had sooo many decades of peace that it's never been 
thought necessary. Ignoring that though, there's a lot of people forced to 
take the tests. Those who fail the extreme tests to use the 3DMG aren't 
even fit to be Titan bait, that's how hard this war is. And as such are 
thrown into the fields to feed humanity which alone is a massive problem. 
(Hence the tens of thousands unarmed "soldiers" sent to reclaim the wall)

5) There's no alternative weapons, that's why. Guns are useless and serve 
only as deterrent to crimes and a distraction to small (<10m) titans. We 
need to kill them from behind. Once they see us, we need to out-maneuver 
them. These blades are the only material we know of capable of cutting hard 
and deep into them. Why fix what isn't broken? It's the best we have.

6) Swords aren't designed to break, it's just the best we have as said in 
the previous question. You seriously underestimate the toughness of the 
Titan's skin, after a while it gets dull and require swapping. In the manga 
these blades are often reclaimed after battles to be reforged and 
sharpened, if not entirely melted down and made anew.

7) Look out for season 2, perhaps that'll be explained then. Otherwise 
manga stuff, don't want spoilers.

8) Look at 3 again, kinda same point. A few 30m titans will probably be 
able to waddle over to it, ignoring the water. If not, well it'll destroy 
any bridges or supports to the city/bridge in the process of trying to get 
back to the surface. Once that's done in a city like that they'll struggle 
to get resources. They'd be starved out within a decade. And we've not even 
consider the Colossal Titan appearing for any of these yet, as it did for 
the show's city, so i'm being generous, really.

9) What weapons? A building? Another titan? Sorry, but pretty sure Eren 
doesn't want to destroy buildings deliberately, he's already being closely 
watched as it is. And he has used titans against titans, quite effectively 
too. Perhaps designing a titan-sized blade for Eren would be a nice idea, 
eh? Costly though, very, very costly. And probably impossible given the 
scale. That's that out the window.

10) It's really not. Entrances are, with several key points of the outer 
rings that are designed to attract attention. No reason for inner walls to 
be manned, is there? And there's no titan agression against the wall 
because it's physically impossible even for a 30m big one to damage it, so 
they've evolved and learnt entrances are the only way in and something they 
know they'll be able to find humans at.

11) Again with the dub? We really didn't forget how to deal with them, 
we've continually over those 100 years had expeditions outside the wall and 
learnt literally loads of very valuable information about our enemy. We've 
continually had newer and newer recruits trained to maintain the wall with 
basic fighting experience if one or two were to get through the entrance 
and we've continually had the "elite" go off and protect the important and 
the rich mostly from other humans. As the sub says though, those who have 
no contact with the titans or training to deal with them, yes, these 
commoners may have forgotten about the threat they posed. That's why 
"Humanity remembered" it's one of the hard-hitting storyline points.

11.5) As for the builders of the wall, well, it's unknown, ain't it? That's 
why so many of the surviving humans believe they've had divine help. We'll 
probably find out more in season 2, but at this point it's not really as 
important as why there's titans in the wall and how they got there. Perhaps 
that's how they started the first walls off, with titan walls?

12) You saw the underground pasages near the end of the anime? They were an 
old sewage system they had going on, suggests they've since replaced it 
with something better or more efficient.

13) Doctors, we've not lost all technology. The closer to the middle you 
get, the more "normal" life is. In a far away town like Eren and Mikasa's 
though, yes, Plague can be a problem. Not sure what the dub says, but 
Eren's dad saved the entire town from a plague once already. And he often 
went inland so we can assume easily he might have had a hand in offering 
vacinations elsewhere too to prevent outbreaks.

14) Subjective. Bad-ass, yes. Annoying, don't see how. As Mikasa puts it, 
he is indecisive. He trusts his fellow humans too much, hence his massively 
delayed reaction to fighting Annie and his inability to believe she's the 
enemy. He still can't believe it either once he actually captures her. 
Remember, he's still human. He ain't even killed a Titan yet in the anime 
or manga at this point as a human, he's still learning.

15) Metal spikes? Stronger than the strongest metal we have available which 
is our steel swords? Well good luck finding some. Jean tried to use his 
sword to break into the crystal, but it's incredibly hard. Harder than 
anything ever seen before. Going titan wouldn't help either, to be honest. 
You're just giving Annie a means to escape.

16) Cos dubs. Dubs are cancer in the Anime world, i'd advise against them 
100%.

17) Because of all the above.
Like, literally the best fanbase i've ever seen. And in general it's just 
such a fucking amazing show.

HOW'S THAT FOR ANSWERS? MWAHAHAHAHA.

TL:DR
SUBS, MANGA (OPTIONAL) AND SEASON 2
I've watched the subs 5 times now, read the manga and are aware of a season 
two announcement early next year to be expected.
If just one season explains everything, we'd have no reason to watch season 
two. :(

comments.text:
+Asher Davis Anime shouldn't be taken as a whole, but in parts. A good 
anime to me should have no plot holes first of all. A single plot hole 
isn't acceptable. Writers are producing works of art, and if they actually 
care about what they are writing, they will make sure it's at least 
sensical. Animation quality isn't crucial, but I consider good animation to 
be both detailed and consistent, not have characters look oddly 
disproportionate at times and sometimes be too lazy to even give them a 
face. I also expect there to be a theme. The writer should have some sort 
of meaningful purpose behind his story. Simply writing nonsensical story 
lines to appease an audience is hardly even art. Art's about expressing 
something about you. If the only motivation you have behind your piece is 
to pander to an audience and don't actually put anything of substance in 
it, then it's about as much as art as the toaster. It's just a convenience. 
The only thing I *didn't* think was crap about SAO was the music. The story 
line was so meaningless, nonsensical and boring, the only reason I got some 
enjoyment out of it was because the compositions were decently captivating. 
But that couldn't even keep me interested to how stupid the second part 
was.

captions.text:
Genetically engineered plants that can detect
bombs could replace expensive electronic detectors
within a decade.

And WASP-43b is a planet 260 light-years away
that features winds blowing at the speed of

sound in 3,000 degree temperatures which is
hot enough to melt steel.
Vsauce! Kevin here. This is Mind Blow.

SpaceWorks Enterprises is designing a deep
sleep transfer habitat to help send humans

to Mars. Funded by NASA, the project aims
to utilize Therapeutic Hypothermia to slow

down astronauts’ metabolisms inducing a
sleep-like inactive state for a prolonged

period of time. Feeding would occur through
intravenous nutritional fluids delivered via

catheter. RhinoChill is an intranasal cooling
system currently used in hospitals to induce

therapeutic hypothermia keeping cardiac arrest
victims in stable condition while waiting

for treatment. But they currently only do
it for up to a week - not the 180 days it

takes to get to Mars. So a lot more research
is needed to understand its long term mental
and physical effects.

RoomAlive transforms your living room into
a video game. It uses projector-depth camera

units to create a unified model of the room
and sends that information to a game engine.

This proof-of-concept includes a holodeck,
a whack-a-mole game using a gun controller,

a robot attack game, and booby trap virtual
darts shooting from the wall that players

try to avoid. All of which are just samples
of how the system creates augmented entertainment
experiences that can be setup in any room.

White-footed sportive Lemurs don't like seeing
their family -- but they still care. So to

let each other know they're okay, they all
pee on the same tree at different times throughout
the night. So yeah.

A bionic eye has allowed this man to see for
the first time in 33 years. I first featured

the Argus II Retinal Prothesis Device on Mind
Blow #59, and now Larry Hester is the seventh

person using it in the United States. A sensor
implanted in his eye picks up light signals

sent from a camera mounted on the glasses
-- not restoring normal eyesight, but allowing

Hester to see flashes of light that help him
differentiate his surroundings, like telling

the difference between a wall and a door.
So far, he says the best moment for him was

seeing, reaching out and touching his wife's
face.
(Can you really see? Yes!)

This is an animated map of a humpback whale’s
song. Michael Deal used shapes resembling

the notation of Gregorian chants to visualize
whales' incredible underwater music and hopes
to further spread awareness for saving whales.

A Swedish truck driver has been using a mind-controlled
prosthetic arm for a year with no complications.

The arm attaches to a titanium implant integrated
with the bone and it’s controlled with his

biological nerves and muscles. And they’re
currently working on sending that communication

back to the brain to provide intuitive sensory
feedback allowing people to also feel with
the prosthetic hand.

Indonesia’s capital is sinking into the
sea and they’re hoping to save it with a

$40 billion dollar project that will take
30 years. Jakarta is dropping between 2.9

and 6.7 inches per year mostly due to groundwater
extraction leaving large caverns under the

city which are collapsing. So the plan is
to construct 17 new islands and a massive

sea wall in Jakarta Bay to protect from flooding
- with a waterfront shaped like the mythical
Garuda bird - the national symbol of Indonesia.

Researchers from the University of Southern
Denmark have created a crystal that can absorb

and release oxygen. A bucket full of the material,
which is a salt made from cobalt, can suck

up and store all the oxygen in a room. It
can be reused many times without losing its

effectiveness and the hope is to someday use
it to drastically lighten oxygen tanks -- a

scuba diver would only need to carry a few
grains of the stuff because the crystal could
absorb oxygen from the water.

Finally, Susi Sie blends art and science by
using analog techniques to explore the mathematical
nature of unusual substances.

I’m gonna leave you with a ping pong playing
robot - and as always thanks for watching.

title: Deep Sleep To Mars -- Mind Blow #88
